author: defipunk
content: Hi everyone, researcher with a PhD in Systems & Networking. Over the last year, I worked for a smallish distributed systems startup, but quit my job a few months ago to focus on working the blockchain field. After trying my hand at some smart contract work, I'd like to go back to my passion and main interest, system development and research. Generally, bought my first bitcoin in 2012 and first eth late 2016/early 2017

author: spacerlady
content: I have. Feel free to ask me some specific questions.

author: spacerlady
content: My biggest issue was the first one was international. Make sure online, is within your country. Verses world wide. I was given a mentor in a different time zone and a career specialist in another country... Then unfortunately since I was into crypto and such I think my mentor had an inferiority complex and when COVID hit. I didn't request a change of mentor when I was bullied into deleting a 4 month repo hooked up to mongo db. Had to contest the money with a bank.

author: spacerlady
content: But have looked into other boot camp. Mainly front end but thinking I'll just skip doing a second front end course and dive into data science or cyber security centric programs.

author: potuz
content: Wow! Sorry for the off-topic but running a BBS in the 80s was hardcore! At that time I was in elementary school and my mom's lab had one VAX that connected to DARPA (direct call from Argentina). That was as close as I could get to "internet"

content: Hello everyone! My name is Mihir, I am a second-year student studying for a Bachelor of Games and Interactive Environments in Australia.  I have experience in programming languages such as C#, Python, Solidity, and JavaScript. In particular, I found Ethereum to be the most innovative because it provides freedom for creating any application on the blockchain. I am definitely excited to work on this protocol full-time!

author: pipermerriam
content: Very happy to see you all here.  I encourage any of you continue to open pull requests towards the `cohort-zero` repository.  If you've spent some time on a topic, maybe try writing down what you know about in your own words to test your understanding, as well as create content for others that come along to follow your breadcrumbs.  If you don't have any specific topics, try to find a question about the protocol for which you don't know the answer.

author: pipermerriam
content: Other great ways to learn stuff are to try and implement them.  Things like RLP encoding and the hexary patricia trie are very accessible and have well established tests for whether you have it correct.  This is another place where you could learn while producing material for others who come along later.  Something like a python implementation of any of these that is focused on readability and simplicity like the eth2.0-specs (https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs) would be really cool to see for any part of the Eth1 protocol.

author: th4s_
content: <@364458974906548225> Is there also room for not so popular research topics, which are not related to core consensus?

author: th4s_
content: For example I would like to improve the current situation around data or analytics. Getting (historical, aggregated,...) data out of nodes has always been a pain. I would like to see  an open-source, non-commercial solution here.

author: jacobkaufmann
content: Hi everyone! I'm Jacob, previously a SDE at amazon in Seattle for a little over 2 years. After following the space for 2+ years I decided to pursue a full-time career in crypto, so I left my job in March 2021 to dedicate my full efforts toward Solidity/web3 development. As far as research topics go, I'm mainly interested in protocol-level mitigations to MEV

author: king_ty774632
content: what is the culture like working with eth core developers?

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm pretty deeply entrenched in it so I don't really have an objective opinion.  It can vary widely.  It's not one team.  You can get a narrow view by listening to the allcoredevs calls.  When we do come together in person there tend to be a lot of deep dives into technical topics.  Do you have a specific questions?

author: king_ty774632
content:
Nothing Specific Just wondering what other people insight was like with the program 
i saw there is a call in a couple minutes 
would it be ok to join that call inside (eip editing)

author: pipermerriam
content: In general it should be fine for you all to join calls that are publicly posted here in the R&D server.  Be polite.  Mute your microphone.  If you're unsure just ask the host.

author: jacobkaufmann
content: I have not, but I should change that! While I am very interested in their efforts, I was not sure whether their work would be within the scope of this apprenticeship

content: Hi All, I've been playing with crypto since 2015.  I recently left a career as a physics/chemistry teacher. I'm currently living in New Orleans.  Looking forward to this program as a means to learn to effectively contribute to open source protocols. --Daniel

author: joxoby
content: Hi all, I'm a SWE working in the Robotics/AI space, based in California. I hold an MS in Applied Mathematics and I have 5+ yrs of experience with C++ and Python. author: grobmeier
content: Hello, my name is Christian and I am a software developer since 1998. I have started to use ETH back in 2016 and always felt it's something great. These days I still believe in blockchain will change *things*, but never had time to look deeper in the tech. I would love to change that and look at the apprenticeship program as a great way to learn. My current day job includes a lot of open source, Java, Java, Java, some JavaScript, PHP and everything else related to Cloud and Web. One of the most exciting things I saw recently was "unstoppable domains".

author: pipermerriam
content: This is focused on the technical.  If your skillset is more on the PM side I'm not exactly sure where to point you.  <@!552133098075193354>?

author: timbeiko
content: <@!487281155679191041> depends on what you want to help with, but getting involved in the Ethereum Cat Herders is probably the best way to contribute to PMing.

author: timbeiko
content: If you already know what you want to work on, then just joining that effort and doing whatever needs to be done is probably the best approach.

author: jarvis_labs
content:
ÁöÜ„Åï„Çì„ÅØ„ÄÅ„ÅØ„Åò„ÇÅ„Åæ„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅHello Everyone. I am Jarvis (JJ).
I am currently a freelance data scientist and meteorological based application developer in Japan.
Originally a physics student and then a  researcher, I am now looking to become a blockchain developer as a see the great possibility for blockchain tech and seeing the usability and development of Ethereum is a great place to start.
I am pretty new to Ethereum and blockchain development less than 6 months but have over 3 years of python development and research experience.
